articles.headline: NBC Opens Olympics With ‘Worst Hand Imaginable’
articles.snippet: The Games are central to the network’s brand, and NBC will have to navigate complications resulting from the pandemic and politics.
articles.abstract: The Games are central to the network’s brand, and NBC will have to navigate complications resulting from the pandemic and politics.

articles.headline: A Change by Apple Is Tormenting Internet Companies, Especially Meta
articles.snippet: Meta’s stock prices plunged after the company reported that Apple’s privacy features would cost it billions this year. It’s not the only tech giant to take a hit.
articles.abstract: Meta’s stock prices plunged after the company reported that Apple’s privacy features would cost it billions this year. It’s not the only tech giant to take a hit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple’s vision of a more private web is not necessarily a more profitable one for internet companies that depend on advertising revenue.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Clyburn Pushes His Pick for Supreme Court, Testing His Sway With Biden
articles.snippet: The highest-ranking Black member of Congress is credited with helping resurrect the president’s 2020 campaign at a critical point. Now he is calling in a favor.
articles.abstract: The highest-ranking Black member of Congress is credited with helping resurrect the president’s 2020 campaign at a critical point. Now he is calling in a favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina was already picturing Judge J. Michelle Childs sitting on the Supreme Court bench in early 2020 when he suggested Joseph R. Biden Jr. could revive his faltering presidential campaign by pledging to nominate the first Black woman to serve there.

articles.headline: ‘Those Who Remain Will Die’: Neighbors Recall Night of Fear in Syria Raid
articles.snippet: In a village in Syria, residents took cover, watched and hid as U.S. forces assaulted the house next door, killing the leader of ISIS.
articles.abstract: In a village in Syria, residents took cover, watched and hid as U.S. forces assaulted the house next door, killing the leader of ISIS.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATMEH, Syria — The neighbors had never heard anything like it.
articles.byline: By Muhammad Haj Kadour and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Raid Targeting ISIS Leader Came After Months of Planning
articles.snippet: President Biden said the attack on Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi was designed to minimize civilian casualties, but then the terrorist leader set off a bomb.
articles.abstract: President Biden said the attack on Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi was designed to minimize civilian casualties, but then the terrorist leader set off a bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: A risky predawn raid by U.S. Special Operations forces that resulted in the death of the Islamic State’s leader on Thursday was set in motion months ago with a tip that the top terrorist was hiding out on the top floor of a house in northwest Syria.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: At CNN, Personal and Corporate Tensions Collide After Jeff Zucker’s Exit
articles.snippet: Inside the media giant, unease has been mounting: over the network’s corporate ownership, the firing of Chris Cuomo and a looming merger with Discovery.
articles.abstract: Inside the media giant, unease has been mounting: over the network’s corporate ownership, the firing of Chris Cuomo and a looming merger with Discovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: One by one, the name-brand news anchors filed in: Wolf Blitzer, Jake Tapper, Dana Bash and some two dozen of their CNN colleagues, dejected, confused and ready to pounce.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin

articles.headline: From Liverpool to London, Tighter Wallets and Colder Homes
articles.snippet: In Britain, prices are rising at the fastest pace in three decades. People on the lowest incomes are running out of ways to cut back, and the worst is yet to come.
articles.abstract: In Britain, prices are rising at the fastest pace in three decades. People on the lowest incomes are running out of ways to cut back, and the worst is yet to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — For the past few weeks Vincent Snowball hasn’t needed to use the weekly food bank that runs out of a church near Liverpool’s city center. But he’s still there each Tuesday, laying out fabric swatches to advertise his upholstering services, and to socialize with the people he grew up with.

articles.headline: Amazon Warehouse in Alabama Is Set to Begin Second Union Election
articles.snippet: Workers overwhelmingly voted down a union last year, but labor regulators threw out the result, citing company misconduct.
articles.abstract: Workers overwhelmingly voted down a union last year, but labor regulators threw out the result, citing company misconduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the first union election at Amazon’s Bessemer, Ala., warehouse early last year, organizers largely avoided visiting workers at home because Covid was raging and few Americans were vaccinated.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Strong Jobs Report Shows Resilient Economy Despite Covid Wave
articles.snippet: A gain of 467,000 jobs in January defied forecasts that the Omicron variant would hobble the labor market.
articles.abstract: A gain of 467,000 jobs in January defied forecasts that the Omicron variant would hobble the labor market.
articles.lead_paragraph: A record-setting spike in coronavirus cases kept millions of workers at home in January and disrupted businesses from coast to coast. But it couldn’t knock the U.S. job-market recovery off course.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Talmon Joseph Smith

articles.headline: Biden Notes Economic Success as Employment and Wages Rise
articles.snippet: President Biden is celebrating a historic year of job gains and trying to shift the narrative amid high inflation and a lingering virus that have many consumers glum.
articles.abstract: President Biden is celebrating a historic year of job gains and trying to shift the narrative amid high inflation and a lingering virus that have many consumers glum.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden on Friday celebrated unexpectedly rapid January hiring and new data that showed historically strong employment gains over the past year, seizing on good news at a moment when consumers are nervous about their prospects thanks to a lingering pandemic and persistent inflation.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Michael D. Shear
